column3: Satan appears to King Herod and advises him to kill the Innocents.
column4: The arrival of the Holy Family in Sāmǝnon.
column5: The vision of Theophilus continued: Satan urges Herod to pursue the Holy Family.
column6: The vision of Theophilus continued: The Holy Family returns from Egypt.
column7: Deacon Michael, the grocer and the ring that was found in the fish.
column8: The Frenchman whose wife was unable to have children.
column9: During the famine of 1120 MM., the Arabs try to plunder the monasteries.
column10: The monk of Dabra Qalǝmon who did not fast.
column11: The monks of Dabra Qalǝmon who were despoiled by Berbers.

column13: Qommos Raphael from Dabra ʾƎnṣǝnā and the sacrament of confession.

column17: The composition of the Wǝddāse Maryam by the Syrian potter.

column19: Three Arabs who were journeying to the Rif.

column21: The priest from Nārdin who was accused because he kept a nun in his house.
column22: The monk, Yǝsḥaq, who prayed for seven years that Saint Mary would appear to him.
column23: The Arab woman who suffered from an issue of blood for many years.

column25: The lamp before the icon of Saint Mary that the priest tipped over.

column29: The European who wanted to steal the bars of the door to the Manger at Bethlehem.
column30: Māryām from Dǝfrā, a child who wanted to receive Communion but was shut up in the house when her family went to church.

column32: The wife of Joseph from Mǝneta Diyāqon, who had no male children.

column34: The cupbearer of the king of France.
column35: The husband who denied Christ when he became poor.
column36: The French artist who fell from the scaffolding while painting frescoes.
column37: The devout Moslem who became a Christian when Saint Mary appeared to him.

column108: The stone-footed man (i. e. a man with the gout) from France.

column122: The virgin who sinned with many lovers.

column137: The story of Saint Menas and his brother.
column138: The election of Patriarch Matthew I ,
column139: The story of Saint Alexius [Abdo l a-Masih], son of Emperor Theodosius.

column141: The woman from Cairo whose children all died.

column143: The nominal Christian from Sidon who encountered a dragon.
column144: The sinful deacon who was healed by a drop of Saint Mary's milk.
column145: The brigand whom the king's soldiers could not kill.
column146: The Emperor of Rome who erected an altar in his palace.

column155: The priest who could only say the Mass of the Virgin Mary.
column156: The knight who wanted to seduce the daughter of the cobbler.
column157: The Jewish boy who received Holy Communion with his Christian companions.
column158: The pregnant woman who was caught by the tide while going to the church of Saint Michael (Mont Saint Michel)
column159: A man who drowned when a pilgrim ship sank is resuscitated.
column160: The divorced wife who prayed for revenge against her rival.
column161: The woman from Rome whose daughter rose up on the anniversary of her death.
column162: The widow who prayed to Saint Mary and saved her only son from death by hanging.
column163: The young man who used to bring roses to the icon of Saint Mary.
column164: The two women who were attacked by robbers on their way to church.
column165: The sister of Emperor Constantine who prayed to know how Saint Mary bore the Word of God, but then failed to recognize her Son when he appeared to her in church.
column166: The young novice whom Saint Mary encouraged to persevere in his vocation
column167: The pious official who was accused of embezzlement and of having an affair with the wife of his lord.
column168: The prioress who became pregnant after sinning with a servant.
column169: A nun sacristan elopes with a priest, but afterwards they repent.
column170: The bee keeper who consulted a sorceress to have more honey.
column171: The pious monk (or: Hebrew from Akhmim) whom Saint Mary made young.
column172: The pious monk scribe who used to write Saint Mary's name in golden ink.
column173: The Moslem whom Saint Mary told to receive baptism. Later, as Bishop of Rome, he cut off his hand because of a carnal thought.
column174: A nun in prison for her faith prays for two virgins.
column175: The sinful woman who despaired when she kept on sinning and swallowed a scorpion.
column176: The prudent monk who suspected that the food that the monks were eating was harmful, but then saw Saint Mary mak1ng it tasty for them.
column177: The woman who was prevented from fasting by her husband.
column178: The noblewoman who was persuaded by her spiritual father to give away her fine clothes.

column180: Saint Mary saves from a lion a pious monk who had drunk too much wine.
column181: The husband who broke his vow that he would live in continence with his wife.
column182: The merchant who distributed as alms the money that had been loaned him by a friend.
column183: The two brothers from Rome, Peter, a deacon, and Stephen, an avaricious magistrate.
column184: Saint Mary saves the soul of a rich sinner who had repented and was planning to build a monastery and become a monk.

column186: The avaricious priest who visited a dying man who loved bribes.
column187: The nun who was dissuaded from eloping with a knight by a vision of Hell.
column188: The shepherd near the church of Saint Paul in Rome who was possessed by a demon.
column189: The monk who has carried by the bretheren to church when he became too sick to walk.

column191: The monk custodian of the church who prayed to see Saint Mary.
column192: The bankrupt merchant to whom Satan offered two pearls if he would deny Christ and Saint Mary.
column193: A herdsman saves his beasts in a storm by praying to Saint Mary.
column194: The pious mower of hay to whom the gatekeeper gave his daughter in marriage.
column195: The rich woman who went with the monks to the manbalis for prayer and there saw a vision of Saint Mary.
column196: The robber whom a bishop was commanded tosbury after he was executed.
column197: The peasant who complained to Saint Mary because she did not reply to his Hail Mary.
column198: The Jewish cowherd who was baptized by his Christian companions.
column199: The mighty Goliath threatens to destroy the monastery of Saint Mary.
column200: The Moslem who found an icon of Saint Mary in his house.
column201: The only son of a king who dedicated himself to Saint Mary.
column202: The young man who was ready to serve Satan, but refused to deny Saint Mary.
column203: A knight tries to seduce the wife of a friend, but she is saved by a vision.
column204: The pious rich man whom Satan served in hopes of destroying him.
column205: The peasant who became rich from other people's goods.
column206: The hypocritical superior of a monastery who pretended to be religious.
column207: The Jew of Constantinople who threw an icon of Saint Mary into the latrine.
column208: The woman from Rome who killed the baby she bore after sleeping with her son
column209: The monk who got himself appointed abbot of another monastery by the king, without the consent of the monks.
column210: The young man who offered the ring he had received from his girl friend to the icon of Saint Mary.
column211: A ship that was about to founder is saved when they pray to Saint Mary.
column212: The Jew who attacked the icon of Saint Mary when he failed to obtain by litigation someone else's property.

column214: The monk who was custodian of a church near a river and drowned while trying to cross to visit his lover.

column358: The robbers who took from a monk his clothes and the cover of an icon of Saint Mary that he was carrying.
